<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Felectric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas%2Four%20insights%2Frenewable%20natural%20gas%20a%20swiss%20army%20knife%20for%20us%20decarbonization%2Frenewable-natural-gas-a-swiss-army-knife-for-us-decarbonization.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="renewable-natural-gas-a-swiss-army-knife-for-us-decarbonization" data-layer-report-name="renewable-natural-gas-a-swiss-army-knife-for-us-decarbonization>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (9 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>

<p><strong>The energy transition is underway.</strong> Corporations and policymakers are embarking on ambitious decarbonization journeys to reduce dependence on fossil fuels. Renewable natural gas (RNG) emerges as an alternative fuel that could contribute to substantial emissions reductions across multiple industries.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This article is a collaborative effort by Kester Brons, Gracie Brown, Nathan Lash, Ruidi Lu, Andjelka Milutinovic, and Greg Santoni representing views from McKinsey’s Electric Power & Natural Gas and Oil & Gas practices.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>At present, fossil natural gas—which comprises 95 percent methane, 5 percent ethane, and trace amounts of other hydrocarbons—is the second largest source of primary energy in the United States, responsible for 33 percent of the country’s energy consumption in 2021.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3fe77b2e-4479-425a-a842-be25946d649b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3fe77b2e-4479-425a-a842-be25946d649b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“US energy facts explained,” US Energy Information Administration, May 2023, accessed October 2023; “Learn about natural gas,” Enbridge.</span></span></span></a></span> And in the last decade, natural gas consumption has grown by approximately 2 percent per year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cbe15279-a593-4231-8783-7d0404ddf1fa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cbe15279-a593-4231-8783-7d0404ddf1fa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Natural gas consumption by end use,” US Energy Information Administration, August 2023, accessed October 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> As natural gas plays a significant role across sectors in the US energy system—including building and industrial heating, transportation, chemicals, and power generation—much infrastructure (such as wells, pipelines, power plants, and liquid natural gas [LNG] export terminals) has been built to extract, transport, and combust natural gas.</p>

<p>RNG is a purified form of waste-derived biogas generated from anaerobic processes and then upgraded to pipeline-quality gas. It is virtually indistinguishable from fossil natural gas (both are more than 95 percent methane).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fb372873-81ae-4583-9b9a-71b80c9f94c6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fb372873-81ae-4583-9b9a-71b80c9f94c6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Renewable natural gas,” United States Environmental Protection Agency, August 3, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> RNG has the potential to decarbonize a portion of the emissions across many sectors and can be a like-for-like (in other words, a “drop-in”) replacement for fossil natural gas—meaning that end users do not have to modify engines, distribution systems, or other equipment when switching.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>RNG can be produced from a variety of sources—with varying costs, availability, and carbon intensity</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>RNG from anaerobic digestion can be made from several waste feedstocks. The four primary feedstocks used today in the United States are landfill waste, agriculture manure, food waste, and wastewater residues, with potential future sources of supply from biomass waste (Exhibit 1).</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/renewable%20natural%20gas%20a%20swiss%20army%20knife%20for%20us%20decarbonization/svgz-us-rng-sidebar-ex1-v6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="There are several possible renewable natural gas feedstocks." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/renewable%20natural%20gas%20a%20swiss%20army%20knife%20for%20us%20decarbonization/svgz-us-rng-sidebar-ex1-v6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p>These feedstocks have varying carbon intensity and costs of capturing and processing the biogas (Exhibit 2).</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/renewable%20natural%20gas%20a%20swiss%20army%20knife%20for%20us%20decarbonization/svgz-us-rng-ex-no-number-v6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Renewable natural gas from anaerobic digestion can be made from various organic waste sources." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/renewable%20natural%20gas%20a%20swiss%20army%20knife%20for%20us%20decarbonization/svgz-us-rng-ex-no-number-v6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p><strong>Landfill waste:</strong> Landfills can capture the naturally emerging biogas from landfill waste, which is then upgraded into RNG. RNG from landfill biogas is the most cost-effective pathway today, as landfills are already legally required to capture the biogas and hence only need to build the upgrading equipment.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bdf6dc68-9455-4a1c-a30a-73b5e40ca3b1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bdf6dc68-9455-4a1c-a30a-73b5e40ca3b1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Final federal plan requirements for municipal solid waste landfills</em>. United States Environmental Protection Agency, May 10, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> As a result, landfill biogas is currently the largest RNG feedstock in the United States (representing around 70 percent of current capacity).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="df7c2041-e8fc-47b3-9bed-7f8565f7cf42"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="df7c2041-e8fc-47b3-9bed-7f8565f7cf42" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Renewable natural gas database, Argonne National Laboratory, May 23, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> However, given that landfills already capture biogas and therefore have much lower associated methane emissions in their baseline, RNG from landfill biogas also delivers the least emission reduction in contrast to natural gas (50 to 60 gCO2e/MJ compared to around 90 to 100 gCO2e/MJ for fossil natural gas).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="401c8397-933a-4422-8c11-1dc363a18c51"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="401c8397-933a-4422-8c11-1dc363a18c51" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“LCFS pathway certified carbon intensities,” California Air Resources Board, May 26, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p><strong>Agriculture manure:</strong> Agriculture manure (for example, from dairy, swine, and chicken) is anaerobically digested into biogas and upgraded into RNG.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4d9f2d83-0cce-4ee6-8d81-20cbd7db63a5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4d9f2d83-0cce-4ee6-8d81-20cbd7db63a5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The microbial process that occurs in oxygen-free or anaerobic conditions produces methane, which can then be collected for RNG production. Anaerobic digestion and upgrading to RNG is capital intensive, which has historically led to low adoption relative to potential.</span></span></span></a></span> RNG from agriculture manure delivers the largest emission reduction due to the avoided methane emissions that would otherwise occur if the manure were not digested.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9b84be24-008d-43d6-b1fe-64fef8f072f9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9b84be24-008d-43d6-b1fe-64fef8f072f9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Renewable natural gas database, Argonne National Laboratory, May 23, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> As a result, it has grown in recent years to about 20 percent of US-announced capacity. Most of this is from dairy farms, as those are the easiest places to collect manure. However, the current costs associated with constructing and operating an anaerobic digestor make production costs nearly twice as high as landfill RNG.</p>

<p><strong>Food waste:</strong> Source-separated organic waste is anaerobically digested into biogas and upgraded into RNG. According to California Air Resources Board’s Current Fuel Pathways Table, RNG from food waste emits between –80 and –30 gCO2e/MJ, the second-highest emission reduction after agricultural manure; however, US supply is limited today as it is challenging to secure adequately separated organic waste.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="10aae51a-b435-4ce7-8f5b-0bbd03707c5f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="10aae51a-b435-4ce7-8f5b-0bbd03707c5f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">California Air Resources Board, May 2023, accessed October 23, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Production costs are comparable to manure-based RNG.</p>

<p><strong>Wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs):</strong> Organic residues from WWTPs can be anaerobically digested into biogas and upgraded into RNG. RNG from WWTP typically has lifecycle emissions of approximately 30 to 40 gCO2e/MJ, leading to a more limited emission reduction than RNG from agricultural manure or food waste.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7f4faf59-26f3-4a57-a498-4c21dffcffcb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7f4faf59-26f3-4a57-a498-4c21dffcffcb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">California Air Resources Board, May 2023, accessed October 23, 2023; <em>Renewable sources of natural gas: Supply and emissions reduction assessment</em>, American Gas Foundation, December 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> However, because it requires digestors, production costs are higher than landfill. Hence the pathway currently has limited supply.</p>

<p><strong>Other biomass waste (not at scale in the United States):</strong> Cover crops and plant by-products are emerging as other sources of biomass feedstock. While these sources are less established in the United States, the ability to develop and commercialize other biomass feedstocks in a low-carbon intensity way, at scale, could expand the potential supply of RNG.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>Depending on the type of waste (feedstock) used to produce RNG, the associated greenhouse gas (GHG) reduction ranges between 50 percent (emissions intensity of approximately 50 grams CO<sub>2</sub> equivalent per megajoule [gCO<sub>2</sub>e/MJ]) and 300 percent (emissions intensity could drop lower than approximately 300 gCO<sub>2</sub>e/MJ) compared to fossil natural gas (90 to 100 gCO<sub>2</sub>e/MJ). This calculation will vary based on feedstock as well as the calculated baseline emissions for natural gas used for comparison (see sidebar, “RNG can be produced from a variety of sources—with varying costs, availability, and carbon intensity").<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9e084932-055b-4b58-b3bc-c9567c13bfcc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9e084932-055b-4b58-b3bc-c9567c13bfcc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“LCFS pathway certified carbon intensities,” California Air Resources Board. Note: Not only the type of waste, but also all the associated baseline emissions from the processes that RNG is replacing influence the GHG reduction potential. Baseline emissions from landfill methane are very different from manure from ruminants like cows and pigs.</span></span></span></a></span> This characteristic, combined with RNG’s ability to be used in existing gas infrastructure without infrastructure modification, points to its physical viability as an alternative to fossil natural gas.</p>

<p>However, because RNG is feedstock limited and is not always economically viable, it is not a silver bullet for decarbonization. Currently, RNG supply represents less than 1 percent of natural gas supply in the United States and, even if supply were built out to utilize all potential feedstock, RNG would represent about 5 to 20 percent of current natural gas demand.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c758544d-8eab-4b34-9db8-602eb092ff33"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c758544d-8eab-4b34-9db8-602eb092ff33" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Renewable sources of natural gas: Supply and emissions reduction assessment</em>, American Gas Foundation, December 2019; McKinsey analysis.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Despite RNG’s supply limitations, it can become an important part of a portfolio of solutions to achieve deep decarbonization, particularly in the near term, as other low-carbon molecules such as hydrogen are still in the early stages of commercial scale-up. Therefore, scaling up RNG—and determining which end-use markets can derive the most value from it—matters in the energy transition.</p>

<p>This article explores the RNG landscape, including the regulatory environment, the prospects and challenges for developers, and potential unlocks to capture value and realize RNG as a sustainable energy source.</p>

<h2>The RNG market and evolving regulations</h2>

<p>Policy addresses three areas of the RNG market: first, which end uses consume RNG; second, the calculation of RNG’s carbon intensity (and therefore its value); and third, where RNG physically comes from and to where it can be sent.</p>

<h3>End uses</h3>

<p>Most RNG goes toward compressed natural gas (CNG) vehicles due to policy incentives, including the federal renewable identification number (RIN) scheme and the Low Carbon Fuel Standard (LCFS) available in British Columbia, California, Oregon, and Washington.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1fc7d1ed-80f9-4d33-ad60-50ce0393c7b3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1fc7d1ed-80f9-4d33-ad60-50ce0393c7b3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/global-energy-perspective-2022">Global Energy Perspective 2022</a></em>, McKinsey, April 26, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Based on our analysis, these policies can provide incentives up to 20 times the value of natural gas.</p>

<p>The CNG market is small—transport represents less than 1 percent of US natural gas demand. The CNG market in CA is already saturated with RNG and will continue to be saturated as growth in EVs outpaces growth in CNG.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3d688031-068d-4627-96bb-c7833c27db83"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3d688031-068d-4627-96bb-c7833c27db83" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">California CNG is already more than 98 percent met with RNG; “Decarbonizing California with renewable natural gas transportation,” Natural Gas Vehicles America, October 2022; <em><em><a href="/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/global-energy-perspective-2022">Global Energy Perspective 2022</a></em></em>, McKinsey, April 26, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Other sectors’ uptake of RNG will largely hinge on policy, including:</p>

<ul>
    <li><strong>Buildings</strong> (26 percent of natural gas [NG] consumption). Several states—including California, Illinois, and Minnesota—have passed policies that facilitate gas utilities blending RNG into their systems.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b8ee33ad-4b52-4373-8364-3c237cf03b68"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b8ee33ad-4b52-4373-8364-3c237cf03b68" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Natural gas explained,” U.S. Energy Information Administration, April 28, 2023; “Hydrogen activity tracker,” American Gas Association, January 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><strong>Power generation</strong> (38 percent of NG consumption). RNG could theoretically earn value in power generation in some states through Renewable Portfolio Standards, though Renewable Energy Certificate (REC) pricing is currently insufficient to spur the RNG market in the power sector.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e0e5c481-d6c3-4e1e-8932-4fdfecc214aa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e0e5c481-d6c3-4e1e-8932-4fdfecc214aa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Natural gas explained,” U.S. Energy Information Administration, April 28, 2023; For example, a Tier 1 renewable energy certificates (REC) in New York State sold for $20.10/MWh in the first quarter of 2023 (assessed October 2023); at a conversion of 0.293 MMBTU per MWh, this implies $5.88/MMBTU from RECs; “2022 compliance year,” Clean Energy Standard, New York State, 2023. By contrast RNG from landfill biogas, the lowest-cost feedstock, costs $11 / MMBTU to produce.</span></span></span></a></span> Alternately, the Environmental Protection Agency’s (EPA) December 2022 proposed rule introduced a potentially more lucrative opportunity to generate RINs via biogas-to-power for electrified transport, but relevant policies were not implemented in the EPA’s final 2023 Renewable Fuel Standards.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9a8c6810-5e5b-45fc-a484-b424d943652d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9a8c6810-5e5b-45fc-a484-b424d943652d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Proposed Rules,” <em>Federal Register</em>, 2022, Volume 87, Number 250; “Renewable Fuel Standard Program,” United States Environmental Protection Agency, December 30, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><strong>Industry</strong> (32 percent of NG consumption). The United States does not have policies promoting the use of RNG in industry. Industrial demand for RNG is instead driven by companies meeting voluntary climate targets.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f2632f75-ac62-4532-8baf-20da4bd73469"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f2632f75-ac62-4532-8baf-20da4bd73469" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Natural gas explained,” U.S. Energy Information Administration, April 28, 2023. For instance, Duke University signed a 20-year agreement with GreenGas USA to purchase 95,000 MMBTUs of RNG to edge the University even closer to meeting its 2024 net-zero commitment; Nora Goldstein, “Duke University seals the deal for RNG,” BioCycle, August 3, 2021; AstraZeneca signed a 15-year agreement with Vanguard Renewables to purchase up to 650,000 MMBTU annually to meet its net-zero targets. Jacob Wallace, “Vanguard Renewables strikes largest open market RNG deal yet with AstraZeneca,” Waste Dive, June 14, 2023</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>

<h3>Carbon intensity</h3>

<p>Under some policy mechanisms, the carbon intensity (CI) of RNG is critical to its value. Therefore, CI accounting policy will influence the relative value of RNG production pathways and which types of RNG go to which end markets.</p>

<p>For example, in California’s LCFS policy today, varying assumptions related to avoided emissions during RNG production result in materially different carbon intensities and associated LCFS credit values across production pathways.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b99839f5-a592-49a0-8637-b753b3cea2a7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b99839f5-a592-49a0-8637-b753b3cea2a7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Low carbon fuel standard public workshop: Concepts and tools for compliance target modeling</em>, California Air Resources Board, November 9, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Agriculture manure is assumed to emit methane in a baseline scenario; as a result, RNG produced by processing that manure is calculated to have a very low CI due to the avoided methane emissions. By contrast, landfills typically have a cap that captures the methane before it is emitted and a limited amount of methane is released to the atmosphere in a baseline scenario—therefore, the CI calculation for RNG from landfills assumes a smaller avoided methane emission, leading to a higher CI (Exhibit 1).</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/renewable%20natural%20gas%20a%20swiss%20army%20knife%20for%20us%20decarbonization/svgz-us-rng-ex3-v5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Production and avoided emissions from creating renewable natural gas are the biggest sources of differentiation in carbon intensity across feedstock." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/renewable%20natural%20gas%20a%20swiss%20army%20knife%20for%20us%20decarbonization/svgz-us-rng-ex3-v5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p>Federal RINs, on the other hand, are calculated on a volumetric basis where each unit of RNG derived from organic waste will yield a RIN, regardless of CI.</p>

<p>As a result of varying incentives for carbon intensity, almost all dairy RNG today flows to the CNG transportation markets in California and states with similar incentive programs (for example, Oregon and Washington). Pathways calculated to have higher CI—such as landfill RNG—are increasingly selling into markets that do not provide financial incentives based on the CI for RNG. However, regulators like the California Air Resources Board are currently considering baseline methane emission calculations.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d330967f-e229-427d-854d-7c7e50ef0f63"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d330967f-e229-427d-854d-7c7e50ef0f63" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Low carbon fuel standard public workshop: Concepts and tools for compliance target modeling</em>, California Air Resources Board, November 9, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<h3>Policy impacts from where, and to whom, RNG can be sold</h3>

<p>The LCFS book-and-claim system means developers do not have to physically deliver RNG to the end consumer, but rather “book” every unit of gas injected into the grid and “claim” consumption when the end user consumes a unit of gas. This means any RNG developer with access to a North American pipeline might sell to a CNG fleet in California and earn LCFS credit value.</p>

<p>Policies impact the way in which end use sectors consume RNG, how much each sector is paying for each RNG production pathway, and from where they buy their RNG. Generally, current policy direction creates tailwinds for the industry.</p>

<h4>Tailwinds are strong, but developers face real challenges</h4>

<p>Recent regulatory changes such as the Inflation Reduction Act’s (IRA) policy guidelines, the EPA’s e-RIN proposal laid out in the 2023 to 2025 Federal Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS), and state blending targets could support an expansion in RNG demand.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="eab5c4ad-7da5-41c1-a3ae-fbcd8445c22e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="eab5c4ad-7da5-41c1-a3ae-fbcd8445c22e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The EPA’s e-RIN proposal was intended to allow biogas projects to earn Renewable Identification Number credits by selling biogas to produce electricity that powers electric vehicles; “Unpacking EPA’s e-RIN proposal, BioCycle, December 20, 2022; Michael Levin, “The IRA revolutionizes AD tax credits,” BioCycle, August 23, 2022; “Proposed Rules,” <em>Federal Register</em>, 2022, Volume 87, Number 250.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition, the IRA could provide tailwinds for RNG development due to a 30 percent biogas Investment Tax Credit (ITC) through 2025, as well as carbon capture and hydrogen production tax credits that make both blue hydrogen and broader clean fuels more attractive.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3d532b62-c1ce-4bc8-bf87-b46273acb38e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3d532b62-c1ce-4bc8-bf87-b46273acb38e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Sec. 45Q. Credit for carbon oxide sequestration,” Bloomberg Tax; “Sec. 45V. Credit for production of clean hydrogen,” Bloomberg Tax.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>RNG capacity in the United States has grown fourfold since 2015, with landfill and agriculture manure projects driving 90 percent of US supply.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2ba2c601-01eb-4db9-8213-530bcc5c1e7f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2ba2c601-01eb-4db9-8213-530bcc5c1e7f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Renewable natural gas database, Argonne National Laboratory, August 2, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Investors and corporates are deploying significant capital into RNG.</p>

<p>Despite the emerging tailwinds, this rapid scale-up and demand shift creates complications for RNG developers:</p>

<ul>
    <li>Current CNG markets are at risk of saturation. The market has historically been the most attractive for RNG; however, growth in US demand for CNG is projected to slow post 2030 as improvements in electric vehicle (EV) battery technology lead to electrification outcompeting CNG in medium-duty and heavy-duty fleets.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e8c32e9c-e00b-49cb-abe8-0962c778b4af"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e8c32e9c-e00b-49cb-abe8-0962c778b4af" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><em><a href="/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/global-energy-perspective-2022">Global Energy Perspective 2022</a></em></em>, McKinsey, April 26, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition, the high volatility of LCFS and RIN prices has developers looking for longer-term fixed price agreements to limit their market price exposure. As the market shifts from CNG, developers seek to identify high-value and longer-term off-takers.</li>
    <li>Cost to produce is increasing. Supply chain and financing costs are driving up project costs and extending development timelines. Meanwhile, project developers are trying to rapidly scale up their execution capabilities, often aiming to build more than ten projects per year (up from approximately three per year), to meet growing demand. Few developers yet have the scale, experience, or bandwidth to implement capital and operational best practices that are needed to drive down project costs.</li>
    <li>Lowest-cost RNG feedstock sources are scarcer. Most US RNG production today comes from large landfills and dairy farms (with more than 5,000 dairy cows) that can deploy larger-scale digesters and hence operate at lower per unit cost than smaller facilities. There is, however, still an untapped long-tail supply of farms (such as swine, chicken, and smaller dairy farms) that are harder to commercialize than large farms, and landfills that are generating biogas today but have not yet upgraded to RNG. While supply potential remains, alternate sources of supply will be harder to develop cost effectively.</li>
</ul>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/how-we-help-clients">Electric Power & Natural Gas Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/how-we-help-clients/midstream-and-downstream-natural-gas" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Visit our Midstream & Downstream Natural Gas page</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>

<h2>Potential unlocks for RNG developers</h2>

<p>To navigate emerging challenges and take steps to capture value, RNG developers who act now could choose to do so in several ways.</p>

<h3>Secure off-takers looking to monetize low-CI products</h3>

<p>As the CNG market saturates and the regulatory environment continues to evolve, developers may seek to diversify customers—such as from CNG fleet owners to a mix of utilities, hydrogen producers, and potentially electric vehicle OEMs—and to diversify exposure to credit schemes. For instance, developers could diversify their current revenue streams from ones reliant on LCFS and RINs to include hydrogen production tax credits, or offtake contracts with utilities that have blending mandates.</p>

<p>There are three primary market opportunities that developers can evaluate, including:</p>

<ul>
    <li><strong>Collaborating with utilities to decarbonize heating, while maintaining customer affordability.</strong> Utilities have regulatory requirements—including those to procure RNG in some states—while maintaining low rates for their customers. Therefore, many utilities will seek to procure RNG on a least-cost per million British thermal units (MMBTU) basis. RNG developers (particularly those with lower cost and higher CI, such as developers producing RNG from landfills) could offer utilities least-cost per MMBTU gas that meets their regulatory requirements while minimizing rate impacts. These utility priorities may shift over time and will likely vary by state, as gas utilities and their regulators evaluate and value decarbonization levers.</li>
    <li><strong>Watching regulatory signposts to monitor e-RINs as a potential opportunity.</strong> LCFS has approved several biogas-to-power pathways for transportation, and the EPA’s December 2022 proposed rule would have created incentives for RNG-to-power projects nationally. However, the rule was not implemented in 2023.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bc65b2fe-d59e-43fa-9b28-5c349d0fafc8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bc65b2fe-d59e-43fa-9b28-5c349d0fafc8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Renewable fuel standards program,” Environmental Protection Agency, December 30, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> If an e-RINs rule is implemented in line with the December 2022 EPA proposed rule, power for EV charging―via offtake contracts with passenger-vehicle OEMs―could be an end market for RNG producers to explore. </li>
    <li><strong>Fueling low-carbon hydrogen production in existing plants.</strong> In the United States, most hydrogen is carbon-intensive “grey” hydrogen, produced via steam methane reformation of fossil natural gas at approximately $1 per kilogram of hydrogen.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e22f5d1b-0fa4-4062-8a3a-d8aaf0a47181"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e22f5d1b-0fa4-4062-8a3a-d8aaf0a47181" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Pathways to commercial liftoff: Clean hydrogen</em>, U.S. Department of Energy, March 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> The IRA incentivizes low-CI hydrogen production. For example, retrofitting existing hydrogen production plants with carbon capture can produce “blue” hydrogen, worth up to $1 per kilogram of incentive value for ten years of project life from the IRA. Pending policy guidance, adding even small blends of carbon-negative RNG—as low as 7 to 10 percent—can qualify for IRA incentives of $3 per kilogram, equating to around $200 per MMBTU for RNG (Exhibit 2). Thus, the combination of negative CI RNG and carbon capture and sequestration (CCS) could potentially be an economically attractive pathway for hydrogen producers.</li>
</ul>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/renewable%20natural%20gas%20a%20swiss%20army%20knife%20for%20us%20decarbonization/svgz-us-rng-ex4-v4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Renewable natural gas can potentially unlock incentives for low-carbon hydrogen production." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/renewable%20natural%20gas%20a%20swiss%20army%20knife%20for%20us%20decarbonization/svgz-us-rng-ex4-v4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<h3>Accelerate development at scale</h3>

<p>Supply will need to triple in the next decade to meet expected demand and decarbonization goals. To scale up supply, RNG project developers will need to build capabilities in capital project development. These include executing several projects in parallel on time and on budget; managing EPC contractors; securing outside financing including debt and federal and local incentives; and overseeing and optimizing ongoing operations across an at-scale project footprint.</p>

<p>Scale itself will create value. As developers scale, they could realize lower cost of capital by grouping multiple projects to capture tax equity via the IRA’s ITC (through 2025). Additionally, larger developers could contract at scale with major customers, like fertilizer companies or gas utilities, thus securing long-term, more stable contracts.</p>

<h3>Commercialize the harder-to-capture potential</h3>

<p>Agriculture manure and landfill biogas are the largest sources of RNG feedstock. Some RNG developers have publicly announced partnerships with large agricultural players, and landfill biogas feedstock is a well-established source of RNG.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="921b2d11-de6e-442d-92df-07743b0bd70f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="921b2d11-de6e-442d-92df-07743b0bd70f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For example, the Roeslein Alternative Energy partnership with Smithfield Foods, and the BioCarbN partnership with Tyson Foods; “Largest RNG project of its kind implements manure-to-energy technology across North Missouri, celebrates construction completion ahead of joint venture’s 10-year anniversary,” Smithfield, August 11, 2021; “NW Natural begins producing RNG at second Tyson Foods facility,” <em>Businesswire</em>, May 2, 2023; per Argonne National Lab, about 70 percent of RNG capacity comes from landfill biogas feedstock.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Nonetheless, smaller-scale farms and landfills with feedstock access remain untapped— currently most cannot justify the high fixed cost of a large-scale digester. For instance, about 90 million to 100 million MMBTU of RNG potential could be obtained from small landfills, although only about 1 to 2 percent of that potential is being used today for RNG production.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6664eeef-62fd-4019-adbb-42e3018deece"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6664eeef-62fd-4019-adbb-42e3018deece" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“RNG navigator tool,” McKinsey, July 17, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>To access these untapped smaller farms and landfills, a developer could:</p>

<ul>
    <li>reduce overall digester costs using modular “plug and play” design technology solutions instead of tailored design solutions</li>
    <li>centralize operational support and maintenance for clusters of facilities</li>
    <li>pool manure from closely located farms to enable the build of single, large-scale digesters instead of individual smaller ones</li>
    <li>combine varying types of feedstocks (for example, agriculture manure and sorted food waste) to increase scale and unlock cost efficiencies</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<p>RNG has significant capacity to grow in the United States, both on the demand and supply side. Developers are starting to aggressively pursue the opportunities that arise. They could take advantage of new offtake sectors, the benefits of development at scale, and the as-yet untapped sources of supply to unleash RNG’s full potential to be a sustainable energy source. This could reduce GHG emissions and propel the transition toward a greener and more resilient future.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Kester Brons</strong> is a consultant in McKinsey’s San Francisco office, where <strong>Gracie Brown</strong> is an associate partner; <strong>Nathan Lash</strong> is an associate partner in the Boston office, where <strong>Ruidi Lu</strong> is a consultant; and <strong>Andjelka Milutinovic</strong> is an associate partner in the Houston office, where <strong>Greg Santoni</strong> is a partner.</p>

1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe energy transition is underway.\u003c/strong\u003e Corporations and policymakers are embarking on ambitious decarbonization journeys to reduce dependence on fossil fuels. Renewable natural gas (RNG) emerges as an alternative fuel that could contribute to substantial emissions reductions across multiple industries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[sidebar authors]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eAt present, fossil natural gas\u0026mdash;which comprises 95 percent methane, 5 percent ethane, and trace amounts of other hydrocarbons\u0026mdash;is the second largest source of primary energy in the United States, responsible for 33 percent of the country\u0026rsquo;s energy consumption in 2021.[[footnote 1]] And in the last decade, natural gas consumption has grown by approximately 2 percent per year.[[footnote 2]] As natural gas plays a significant role across sectors in the US energy system\u0026mdash;including building and industrial heating, transportation, chemicals, and power generation\u0026mdash;much infrastructure (such as wells, pipelines, power plants, and liquid natural gas [LNG] export terminals) has been built to extract, transport, and combust natural gas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eRNG is a purified form of waste-derived biogas generated from anaerobic processes and then upgraded to pipeline-quality gas. It is virtually indistinguishable from fossil natural gas (both are more than 95 percent methane).[[footnote 3]] RNG has the potential to decarbonize a portion of the emissions across many sectors and can be a like-for-like (in other words, a \u0026ldquo;drop-in\u0026rdquo;) replacement for fossil natural gas\u0026mdash;meaning that end users do not have to modify engines, distribution systems, or other equipment when switching.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[sidebar 1]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eDepending on the type of waste (feedstock) used to produce RNG, the associated greenhouse gas (GHG) reduction ranges between 50 percent (emissions intensity of approximately 50 grams CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e equivalent per megajoule [gCO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003ee/MJ]) and 300 percent (emissions intensity could drop lower than approximately 300 gCO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003ee/MJ) compared to fossil natural gas (90 to 100 gCO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003ee/MJ). This calculation will vary based on feedstock as well as the calculated baseline emissions for natural gas used for comparison (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;RNG can be produced from a variety of sources\u0026mdash;with varying costs, availability, and carbon intensity\").[[footnote 4]] This characteristic, combined with RNG\u0026rsquo;s ability to be used in existing gas infrastructure without infrastructure modification, points to its physical viability as an alternative to fossil natural gas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, because RNG is feedstock limited and is not always economically viable, it is not a silver bullet for decarbonization. Currently, RNG supply represents less than 1 percent of natural gas supply in the United States and, even if supply were built out to utilize all potential feedstock, RNG would represent about 5 to 20 percent of current natural gas demand.[[footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eDespite RNG\u0026rsquo;s supply limitations, it can become an important part of a portfolio of solutions to achieve deep decarbonization, particularly in the near term, as other low-carbon molecules such as hydrogen are still in the early stages of commercial scale-up. Therefore, scaling up RNG\u0026mdash;and determining which end-use markets can derive the most value from it\u0026mdash;matters in the energy transition.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThis article explores the RNG landscape, including the regulatory environment, the prospects and challenges for developers, and potential unlocks to capture value and realize RNG as a sustainable energy source.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eThe RNG market and evolving regulations\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003ePolicy addresses three areas of the RNG market: first, which end uses consume RNG; second, the calculation of RNG\u0026rsquo;s carbon intensity (and therefore its value); and third, where RNG physically comes from and to where it can be sent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eEnd uses\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eMost RNG goes toward compressed natural gas (CNG) vehicles due to policy incentives, including the federal renewable identification number (RIN) scheme and the Low Carbon Fuel Standard (LCFS) available in British Columbia, California, Oregon, and Washington.[[footnote 6]] Based on our analysis, these policies can provide incentives up to 20 times the value of natural gas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe CNG market is small\u0026mdash;transport represents less than 1 percent of US natural gas demand. The CNG market in CA is already saturated with RNG and will continue to be saturated as growth in EVs outpaces growth in CNG.[[footnote 7]] Other sectors\u0026rsquo; uptake of RNG will largely hinge on policy, including:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBuildings\u003c/strong\u003e (26 percent of natural gas [NG] consumption). Several states\u0026mdash;including California, Illinois, and Minnesota\u0026mdash;have passed policies that facilitate gas utilities blending RNG into their systems.[[footnote 8]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePower generation\u003c/strong\u003e (38 percent of NG consumption). RNG could theoretically earn value in power generation in some states through Renewable Portfolio Standards, though Renewable Energy Certificate (REC) pricing is currently insufficient to spur the RNG market in the power sector.[[footnote 9]] Alternately, the Environmental Protection Agency\u0026rsquo;s (EPA) December 2022 proposed rule introduced a potentially more lucrative opportunity to generate RINs via biogas-to-power for electrified transport, but relevant policies were not implemented in the EPA\u0026rsquo;s final 2023 Renewable Fuel Standards.[[footnote 10]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIndustry\u003c/strong\u003e (32 percent of NG consumption). The United States does not have policies promoting the use of RNG in industry. Industrial demand for RNG is instead driven by companies meeting voluntary climate targets.[[footnote 11]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eCarbon intensity\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eUnder some policy mechanisms, the carbon intensity (CI) of RNG is critical to its value. Therefore, CI accounting policy will influence the relative value of RNG production pathways and which types of RNG go to which end markets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eFor example, in California\u0026rsquo;s LCFS policy today, varying assumptions related to avoided emissions during RNG production result in materially different carbon intensities and associated LCFS credit values across production pathways.[[footnote 12]] Agriculture manure is assumed to emit methane in a baseline scenario; as a result, RNG produced by processing that manure is calculated to have a very low CI due to the avoided methane emissions. By contrast, landfills typically have a cap that captures the methane before it is emitted and a limited amount of methane is released to the atmosphere in a baseline scenario\u0026mdash;therefore, the CI calculation for RNG from landfills assumes a smaller avoided methane emission, leading to a higher CI (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eFederal RINs, on the other hand, are calculated on a volumetric basis where each unit of RNG derived from organic waste will yield a RIN, regardless of CI.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eAs a result of varying incentives for carbon intensity, almost all dairy RNG today flows to the CNG transportation markets in California and states with similar incentive programs (for example, Oregon and Washington). Pathways calculated to have higher CI\u0026mdash;such as landfill RNG\u0026mdash;are increasingly selling into markets that do not provide financial incentives based on the CI for RNG. However, regulators like the California Air Resources Board are currently considering baseline methane emission calculations.[[footnote 13]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003ePolicy impacts from where, and to whom, RNG can be sold\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe LCFS book-and-claim system means developers do not have to physically deliver RNG to the end consumer, but rather \u0026ldquo;book\u0026rdquo; every unit of gas injected into the grid and \u0026ldquo;claim\u0026rdquo; consumption when the end user consumes a unit of gas. This means any RNG developer with access to a North American pipeline might sell to a CNG fleet in California and earn LCFS credit value.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003ePolicies impact the way in which end use sectors consume RNG, how much each sector is paying for each RNG production pathway, and from where they buy their RNG. Generally, current policy direction creates tailwinds for the industry.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch4\u003eTailwinds are strong, but developers face real challenges\u003c/h4\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eRecent regulatory changes such as the Inflation Reduction Act\u0026rsquo;s (IRA) policy guidelines, the EPA\u0026rsquo;s e-RIN proposal laid out in the 2023 to 2025 Federal Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS), and state blending targets could support an expansion in RNG demand.[[footnote 14]] In addition, the IRA could provide tailwinds for RNG development due to a 30 percent biogas Investment Tax Credit (ITC) through 2025, as well as carbon capture and hydrogen production tax credits that make both blue hydrogen and broader clean fuels more attractive.[[footnote 15]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eRNG capacity in the United States has grown fourfold since 2015, with landfill and agriculture manure projects driving 90 percent of US supply.[[footnote 16]] Investors and corporates are deploying significant capital into RNG.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eDespite the emerging tailwinds, this rapid scale-up and demand shift creates complications for RNG developers:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCurrent CNG markets are at risk of saturation. The market has historically been the most attractive for RNG; however, growth in US demand for CNG is projected to slow post 2030 as improvements in electric vehicle (EV) battery technology lead to electrification outcompeting CNG in medium-duty and heavy-duty fleets.[[footnote 17]] In addition, the high volatility of LCFS and RIN prices has developers looking for longer-term fixed price agreements to limit their market price exposure. As the market shifts from CNG, developers seek to identify high-value and longer-term off-takers.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCost to produce is increasing. Supply chain and financing costs are driving up project costs and extending development timelines. Meanwhile, project developers are trying to rapidly scale up their execution capabilities, often aiming to build more than ten projects per year (up from approximately three per year), to meet growing demand. Few developers yet have the scale, experience, or bandwidth to implement capital and operational best practices that are needed to drive down project costs.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eLowest-cost RNG feedstock sources are scarcer. Most US RNG production today comes from large landfills and dairy farms (with more than 5,000 dairy cows) that can deploy larger-scale digesters and hence operate at lower per unit cost than smaller facilities. There is, however, still an untapped long-tail supply of farms (such as swine, chicken, and smaller dairy farms) that are harder to commercialize than large farms, and landfills that are generating biogas today but have not yet upgraded to RNG. While supply potential remains, alternate sources of supply will be harder to develop cost effectively.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n[[disruptor1up learnmore]]\n\n\u003ch2\u003ePotential unlocks for RNG developers\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eTo navigate emerging challenges and take steps to capture value, RNG developers who act now could choose to do so in several ways.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eSecure off-takers looking to monetize low-CI products\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eAs the CNG market saturates and the regulatory environment continues to evolve, developers may seek to diversify customers\u0026mdash;such as from CNG fleet owners to a mix of utilities, hydrogen producers, and potentially electric vehicle OEMs\u0026mdash;and to diversify exposure to credit schemes. For instance, developers could diversify their current revenue streams from ones reliant on LCFS and RINs to include hydrogen production tax credits, or offtake contracts with utilities that have blending mandates.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThere are three primary market opportunities that developers can evaluate, including:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCollaborating with utilities to decarbonize heating, while maintaining customer affordability.\u003c/strong\u003e Utilities have regulatory requirements\u0026mdash;including those to procure RNG in some states\u0026mdash;while maintaining low rates for their customers. Therefore, many utilities will seek to procure RNG on a least-cost per million British thermal units (MMBTU) basis. RNG developers (particularly those with lower cost and higher CI, such as developers producing RNG from landfills) could offer utilities least-cost per MMBTU gas that meets their regulatory requirements while minimizing rate impacts. These utility priorities may shift over time and will likely vary by state, as gas utilities and their regulators evaluate and value decarbonization levers.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWatching regulatory signposts to monitor e-RINs as a potential opportunity.\u003c/strong\u003e LCFS has approved several biogas-to-power pathways for transportation, and the EPA\u0026rsquo;s December 2022 proposed rule would have created incentives for RNG-to-power projects nationally. However, the rule was not implemented in 2023.[[footnote 18]] If an e-RINs rule is implemented in line with the December 2022 EPA proposed rule, power for EV charging―via offtake contracts with passenger-vehicle OEMs―could be an end market for RNG producers to explore. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFueling low-carbon hydrogen production in existing plants.\u003c/strong\u003e In the United States, most hydrogen is carbon-intensive \u0026ldquo;grey\u0026rdquo; hydrogen, produced via steam methane reformation of fossil natural gas at approximately $1 per kilogram of hydrogen.[[footnote 19]] The IRA incentivizes low-CI hydrogen production. For example, retrofitting existing hydrogen production plants with carbon capture can produce \u0026ldquo;blue\u0026rdquo; hydrogen, worth up to $1 per kilogram of incentive value for ten years of project life from the IRA. Pending policy guidance, adding even small blends of carbon-negative RNG\u0026mdash;as low as 7 to 10 percent\u0026mdash;can qualify for IRA incentives of $3 per kilogram, equating to around $200 per MMBTU for RNG (Exhibit 2). Thus, the combination of negative CI RNG and carbon capture and sequestration (CCS) could potentially be an economically attractive pathway for hydrogen producers.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 2]]\n\n\u003ch3\u003eAccelerate development at scale\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eSupply will need to triple in the next decade to meet expected demand and decarbonization goals. To scale up supply, RNG project developers will need to build capabilities in capital project development. These include executing several projects in parallel on time and on budget; managing EPC contractors; securing outside financing including debt and federal and local incentives; and overseeing and optimizing ongoing operations across an at-scale project footprint.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eScale itself will create value. As developers scale, they could realize lower cost of capital by grouping multiple projects to capture tax equity via the IRA\u0026rsquo;s ITC (through 2025). Additionally, larger developers could contract at scale with major customers, like fertilizer companies or gas utilities, thus securing long-term, more stable contracts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eCommercialize the harder-to-capture potential\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eAgriculture manure and landfill biogas are the largest sources of RNG feedstock. Some RNG developers have publicly announced partnerships with large agricultural players, and landfill biogas feedstock is a well-established source of RNG.[[footnote 20]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eNonetheless, smaller-scale farms and landfills with feedstock access remain untapped\u0026mdash; currently most cannot justify the high fixed cost of a large-scale digester. For instance, about 90 million to 100 million MMBTU of RNG potential could be obtained from small landfills, although only about 1 to 2 percent of that potential is being used today for RNG production.[[footnote 21]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eTo access these untapped smaller farms and landfills, a developer could:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ereduce overall digester costs using modular \u0026ldquo;plug and play\u0026rdquo; design technology solutions instead of tailored design solutions\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ecentralize operational support and maintenance for clusters of facilities\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003epool manure from closely located farms to enable the build of single, large-scale digesters instead of individual smaller ones\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ecombine varying types of feedstocks (for example, agriculture manure and sorted food waste) to increase scale and unlock cost efficiencies\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eRNG has significant capacity to grow in the United States, both on the demand and supply side. Developers are starting to aggressively pursue the opportunities that arise. They could take advantage of new offtake sectors, the benefits of development at scale, and the as-yet untapped sources of supply to unleash RNG\u0026rsquo;s full potential to be a sustainable energy source. This could reduce GHG emissions and propel the transition toward a greener and more resilient future.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":true},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-11-21T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;US energy facts explained,\u0026rdquo; US Energy Information Administration, May 2023, accessed October 2023; \u0026ldquo;Learn about natural gas,\u0026rdquo; Enbridge.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Natural gas consumption by end use,\u0026rdquo; US Energy Information Administration, August 2023, accessed October 2023.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Renewable natural gas,\u0026rdquo; United States Environmental Protection Agency, August 3, 2023.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;LCFS pathway certified carbon intensities,\u0026rdquo; California Air Resources Board. waste feedstocks. The four primary feedstocks used today in the United States are landfill waste, agriculture manure, food waste, and wastewater residues, with potential future sources of supply from biomass waste (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit side1]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eThese feedstocks have varying carbon intensity and costs of capturing and processing the biogas (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit side2]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLandfill waste:\u003c/strong\u003e Landfills can capture the naturally emerging biogas from landfill waste, which is then upgraded into RNG. RNG from landfill biogas is the most cost-effective pathway today, as landfills are already legally required to capture the biogas and hence only need to build the upgrading equipment.[[footnote 1]] As a result, landfill biogas is currently the largest RNG feedstock in the United States (representing around 70 percent of current capacity).[[footnote 2]] However, given that landfills already capture biogas and therefore have much lower associated methane emissions in their baseline, RNG from landfill biogas also delivers the least emission reduction in contrast to natural gas (50 to 60 gCO2e/MJ compared to around 90 to 100 gCO2e/MJ for fossil natural gas).[[footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAgriculture manure:\u003c/strong\u003e Agriculture manure (for example, from dairy, swine, and chicken) is anaerobically digested into biogas and upgraded into RNG.[[footnote 4]] RNG from agriculture manure delivers the largest emission reduction due to the avoided methane emissions that would otherwise occur if the manure were not digested.[[footnote 5]] As a result, it has grown in recent years to about 20 percent of US-announced capacity. Most of this is from dairy farms, as those are the easiest places to collect manure. However, the current costs associated with constructing and operating an anaerobic digestor make production costs nearly twice as high as landfill RNG.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFood waste:\u003c/strong\u003e Source-separated organic waste is anaerobically digested into biogas and upgraded into RNG. According to California Air Resources Board\u0026rsquo;s Current Fuel Pathways Table, RNG from food waste emits between \u0026ndash;80 and \u0026ndash;30 gCO2e/MJ, the second-highest emission reduction after agricultural manure; however, US supply is limited today as it is challenging to secure adequately separated organic waste.[[footnote 6]] Production costs are comparable to manure-based RNG.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWastewater treatment plants (WWTPs):\u003c/strong\u003e Organic residues from WWTPs can be anaerobically digested into biogas and upgraded into RNG. RNG from WWTP typically has lifecycle emissions of approximately 30 to 40 gCO2e/MJ, leading to a more limited emission reduction than RNG from agricultural manure or food waste.[[footnote 7]] However, because it requires digestors, production costs are higher than landfill. Hence the pathway currently has limited supply.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOther biomass waste (not at scale in the United States):\u003c/strong\u003e Cover crops and plant by-products are emerging as other sources of biomass feedstock. While these sources are less established in the United States, the ability to develop and commercialize other biomass feedstocks in a low-carbon intensity way, at scale, could expand the potential supply of RNG.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"RNG can be produced from a variety of sources\u0026mdash;with varying costs, availability, and carbon intensity"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFinal federal plan requirements for municipal solid waste landfills\u003c/em\u003e.
